FacilityName: Charles A. Strain Water Treatment Plant

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires that all facilities (both public and private) which utilize specific hazardous chemicals above defined threshold quantities in their processes, be in compliance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act (CAA) 40 CFR 112r Part 68.  The Clifton Water District (CWD) utilizes liquefied chlorine in the treatment of water for use by the public.  Chlorine is on the list of hazardous chemicals covered by the threshold limits within the CAA.  The requirements presented in the CAA regarding processes that utilize hazardous chemicals identify specific safety precautions regarding handling and storage of the listed hazardous chemicals.  The Clifton Water District has specific release prevention and emergency response procedures in place to help prevent chemical exposure to water treatment personnel as well as the general public, given the life, health and safety hazards associated with liquefied chlorine.  It is the policy of the CWD to strictly adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules, regulations, and safety precautions.

It is the opinion of the Clifton Water District?s Board of Directors and Management that the emergency action response plan utilized by the CWD is in compliance with OSHA?s Employee Emergency and Fire Prevention Plan, 29 CFR Part 1910.38.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for notifying the Clifton Fire District and the Grand Junction Fire Department?s Hazardous Materials Team (HAZMAT) to respond to hazardous chemical releases at the water treatment plant, and to notify all potentially affected neighbors.

Facility Description and Activities

The Clifton Water District provides domestic potable water to approximately 35,000 customers located in the unincorporated portion of Mesa County, generally referred to as `Clifton? (roughly the area encompassed from I-70 to the Colorado River and 30 Road t

o 34.5 Road), along with a detached service area in the vicinity of Whitewater, CO.  The water treatment plant, along with the main business office is located at 510 34 Road, Clifton, CO.  The CWD processes water from the Colorado River through conventional water treatment practices as well as additional finish water treatment through a process utilizing membrane technology.

Liquefied chlorine is delivered in one-ton bulk containers by certified chemical transportation companies to the water treatment plant where it is off-loaded into the enclosed chlorine storage/feed room where the containers are connected to an automatic vacuum manifold system.  The chlorine is fed to the treated water as a part of the final disinfection process prior to delivery to the end user.  The feed system utilizes two one-ton containers that are automatically switched from empty to full via the vacuum manifold system.  The system is on a routine monitoring regimen by treatment plant personnel as well as continuous monitoring by leak sensors that are connected to both visual and audio alarm mechanisms both inside and outside the plant.  During off-normal hours, the alarm system is connected to a remote dialer that notifies on-call personnel if a leak occurs so that appropriate response can be initiated.

Access to the water treatment plant facility is controlled via locked automatic gates and security fencing surrounding the facility.  The chlorine room is locked at all times to prevent unauthorized access.  All treatment plant personnel are thoroughly trained regarding the hazards and risks associated with liquefied chlorine for both themselves and the general public.  Specific regulatory operational and maintenance procedures are in place and strictly followed by all plant personnel.  Procedural and personnel audits are performed on an annual basis to identify hazards or risks that may have been overlooked or not previously identified.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps

It is the opinion of the Clifton Water District Board of Directors and Management that the Clifton Water District?s water treatment plant is currently in compliance with the EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention rule and all applicable State of Colorado Codes and regulations.  The original water treatment plant, and chlorine handling area, was constructed in 1979 to all applicable codes and building requirements in force at that time.  The plant underwent expansion in 1981 and again in 1997.  Each time the plant was expanded, all applicable codes and requirements were followed and recommended chlorine handling modifications were implemented.  In 1999, the District identified the need for a revamped chlorine handling and feed facility.  This new facility is currently under construction and is scheduled to be placed in service by October 2004.  The current system equipment and components related to receiving, feed process and final discharge of chlorine are inspected daily by trained plant personnel and maintained and serviced according to equipment manufacturer?s recommendations.  The water treatment personnel have been trained to follow specific operational and maintenance procedures while utilizing the chlorine process.

Since January 1999, the treatment plant personnel have performed their own testing and maintenance of chlorine feed components.  The District?s treatment plant staff has purchased the necessary equipment to build and maintain their own chlorine testing apparatus.  The testing apparatus is fully functional and is used to test individual components of the chlorine feed and monitoring process.

Plant personnel perform daily checks and inspections of the chlorine handling/storage/feed system and a scheduled maintenance system is in place.  Chlorine release detection sensors are located in the stor

age/feed area and are set to alarm if a release is detected.  The alarms are both visual (exterior mounted strobe light) and audible (located both inside the plant and on the exterior).  During off-normal hours, the detector sensors also alarm an automatic phone dialer that notifies key on-call personnel that a release has occurred.  Specific activity procedures are in place for off-normal hour emergency notifications.

Five-Year Accident History

The Clifton Water District has not ever had any accidental releases since the plant was constructed in 1979.

Emergency Response Program

It is the opinion of the Clifton Water District?s Board of Directors and Management that the Clifton Water District?s emergency response plan is currently in compliance with the EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention rule and all applicable State of Colorado Codes and regulations.  The response plan is supported by the Mesa County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the Clifton Fire District, and the Grand Junction Fire Department?s HAZMAT Team.  The Clifton Fire District and the Grand Junction Fire Department?s HAZMAT Team have toured the water treatment plant and are prepared for and are ready to respond to releases at this facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Clifton Water District continually reviews processes and practices regarding the operation of the water treatment plant and its specific components (eg. the chlorine handling/storage/feed system component).  If hazards and risks are identified, that were previously overlooked or not identified, changes to practice and procedure are implemented as needed.  As a part of the District?s five-year capital improvement plan, the chlorine handling/storage/feed facility is being upgraded and is in construction at this time.  A new facility will be on-line in October 2004.  The new facility will reflect current State of Colorado and Chlorine Institute requirements as well as new security upgrades.  This RMP will be updated

at the time the new facility comes on-line.  The treatment plant operators are continually reviewing and evaluating new technologies and methods for potable water disinfection.  If a new technology or methodology were to be identified and developed that presents itself to the unique treatment requirements of the Clifton Water District?s water source that reduce or eliminate the need for using liquefied chlorine,  evaluation and consideration of cost-effective outcomes would be pursued.
